choices.A: Using session attributes, store the previous question as the context for use in the AMAZON.YesIntent handler.
choices.C: Within the AMAZON.YesIntent handler, define a slot to store and retrieve the previously asked question.
choices.B: Within the AMAZON.YesIntent handler, prompt the user to repeat the name of the animal that they like.
choices.D: Access Amazon CloudWatch Logs and retrieve the previous question topic from the recent log messages.

discussion.content: The answer is A. You can't define slots on with the Amazon.YesIntent.

questions.question_text:
An Alexa Skill Builder wants to create a skill that asks the user two yes/no questions:
Alexa: Do you like cats?
Alexa: Do you like dogs?
When the username answers "yes", how should the Builder code the handler to know which question the answer refers to?

choices.A: Manually extend the timeout so that users can input all the numbers.
choices.C: Enter single digits one request at a time.
choices.B: Use multiple requests for smaller segments of the code and store the data in session attributes.
choices.D: Request that users send the number using the Amazon Alexa app

questions.question_text:
An Alexa Skill Builder is building an order reporting skill. Occasionally, users need to enter 30-digit serial codes.
How can this be accomplished while providing a good voice user interface experience?

discussion.content:
The answer is C.
Voice & Tone
 

Enter plain text or [SSML][ssml_ref] and hear how Alexa speaks the text. Select the language you want to hear from the list at the bottom. All supported languages are available in this list, even if your skill doesn't support them.

Before beginning the development of a skill, an Alexa Skill Builder wants to hear how a statement will be pronounced by Amazon Alexa in another locale.
How should the Builder test the pronounciation of the statement?

choices.B: Create a developer account for the specific locale, and use a device to interact with the skill.
choices.C: Use Voice & Tone tab in the developer console to play the statement using the selected locale.
choices.D: Use the Manual JSON tab in the developer console to create a sample JSON response

questions.question_text:
An Alexa Skill Builder is developing a skill containing a multi-turn dialog that can be invoked with or without a specific intent request. On invocation, the skill needs to retrieve persistent attributes that have been saved by a previous invocation, and then copy them into session attributes.
How should the Builder implement this functionality?

discussion.content: The answer is D. The request interceptor should only update the session attributes with the persisted values if it's a new session.

choices.B: Implement ResponseInterceptor containing logic that takes the current persistent attributes and copies them into session attributes.
choices.C: Include logic within the LaunchRequest intent handler to retrieve persistent attributes and copy them into session attributes.
choices.D: Implement RequestInterceptor containing logic which for new sessions, retrieves persistent attributes and copies them into session attributes
choices.A: Place logic within the skill's SessionEndedRequest intent handler to copy the persistent attributes into the session attributes.

questions.question_text:
An Alexa Skill Builder has built a new custom skill backed by an AWS Lambda function. The Lambda function executes successfully from the Lambda console, however, the Lambda function cannot be successfully invoked in the developer console or from an Amazon Alexa enabled device. No error messages show in the function's Amazon CloudWatch Logs. The Builder confirmed the endpoint has the correct ARN.
What is likely causing this issue and how can it be corrected?

discussion.content:
C. https://developer.amazon.com/en-US/docs/alexa/custom-skills/handle-requests-sent-by-alexa.html
If you host your skill with AWS Lambda, you can provide your skill ID as part of the Alexa Skills Kit trigger. This adds a verification check before your function is ever invoked, so unverified skills cannot invoke your function. In this case, you do not need to check the skill ID in your code.

choices.A: The Lambda application code has a bug that is causing it to crash. Modify the code to fix the bug, then redeploy the Lambda function.
choices.D: The Lambda role does not have the correct AWS IAM permission. Update the IAM role associated with the Lambda function.
choices.B: The ASK SDK was not deployed with the Lambda function. Add the ASK SDK, then redeploy the Lambda function.
choices.C: The ASK trigger for the Lambda function has been restricted to the wrong skill ID. Re-create the trigger with the correct skill ID.
